author: Zoe Taylor
title: How starting a business helped me swim the English Channel
text:
Its a question of backing yourself and your own ability confidence is all in the mind.
Mark Sowerby knows something about risk, and the self-belief needed to crash through the fear of losing everything.
Sowerby bet everything he owned on launching a fund management business on the eve of the GFC. At a time when investors were fleeing the market Sowerby was ploughing money in via his Blue Sky Alternative Investments fund, which funded small to medium firms.
Getting his company off the ground during the chaos of the financial crisis led to many sleepless nights, but Brisbane-based Sowerby, says that self-belief is in his DNA.
“It’s a question of backing yourself and your own ability,” he says, although he also credits the support of his “smarter and stronger” wife Heidi.
Sowerby is also a firm believer of crashing through your comfort zones – repeatedly. His most recent “grand final” of a challenge was completing a swim of the English Channel.
Mark Sowerby had to swim through the busiest shipping lane in the world. Source: supplied Source: DailyTelegraph
“When I was training for the swim, I was told that when you get to the point where you feel you have nothing left, you have at least three more levels to go. And that is right,” he says.
Towards the end of his 14-hour swim, it was essential to sprint for at least 45 minutes or else risk being swept off course and not finishing. Sowerby managed to sprint.
Sowerby had to sprint the final 45 minutes of his 14 hour swim to avoid being swept off course. Source: Supplied Source: DailyTelegraph
“Whether it’s a physical challenge or work one, confidence is all in the mind,” he says. “It comes from facing tough situations and proving you can get through them. Things do go wrong, but you use that experience to see how things might work next time.”
Sowerby found that controlling the mind was key to processing the fears that kept him awake at night during the nerve-racking early years of starting his company. By breaking challenges down into ‘bite-sized’ chunks and resisting looking too far into the future he managed keep his nerve and avoid a crisis of confidence while investing his own and other people’s money successfully. Blue Sky grew its market capitalisation by 216 per cent in 2013 to $90 million and is expected to have $2 billion under management, giving an annual compounded return of 20 per cent to investors by 2017.
Face up to your fears: Dr Barbara Grace, of the School of Modern Psychology, also uses a water analogy to explain self-belief – imagining the choices a sailor is faced with when a smooth sail suddenly becomes rough and difficult.
“The sailor has two options,” she says. “Change course to somewhere that’s easier to get to, or carry on. Most people change course, head for a safe harbour and tell themselves it was just bad luck or poor conditions.”
The temptation is to believe the problem is external. What sets apart those who are able to conquer challenges of self-belief is a willingness to face up to fear and the possibility of failure, she says.
Get comfortable with feeling uncomfortable: “The emotions that arise when facing something really scary – like bungy jumping – trigger a complex domino-effect of hormone production that releases cortisol into the blood stream, raising blood pressure and heart rate. Usually, we equate this feeling with fear and we naturally want to retreat.”
However, some people, including extreme sports enthusiasts, equate this rush of hormones with joy and excitement rather than fear – managing to ‘re-frame’ the feeling.
“To get around the flight response it’s important to become comfortable with feeling uncomfortable,” Grace adds. “Breaking patterns around how we code these emotions is key to altering perception and ultimately breaking limiting beliefs,” Grace adds.
Takeaways
Jack Delosa, founder of the entrepreneur community Entourage, has three top tips for avoiding a crisis of confidence:
● The early days of any business are going to be a rollercoaster ride , recognise that one minute you will be up and confident, the next you will be challenged and feeling down. The bad times will pass.
● Don’t compare yourself to others. Whether you’re Richard Branson or someone on their first day in business - we’re all making it up as we go along.
● Emotional fortitude is something that develops like a muscle. The more you carry, the stronger you become. Take each challenge as it comes and pick up the wisdom in every crisis.
Mark Sowerby after his 14 hour swim across the English Channel. Source: DailyTelegraph
Footnote: Mark Sowerby raised more than $800,000 for the Starlight Children’s Foundation from his swim.
